replaced_by: ALTER DEFAULT PRIVILEGES with ROUTINES keyword
reason: Starting with PostgreSQL version 18, the SQL standard prefers the term 'ROUTINES' instead of 'FUNCTIONS' when addressing both functions and procedures together. This change aligns PostgreSQL's syntax with the SQL standard. In earlier releases, only the 'FUNCTIONS' keyword was allowed.

examples.code:
ALTER DEFAULT PRIVILEGES IN SCHEMA myschema GRANT SELECT ON TABLES TO PUBLIC;
ALTER DEFAULT PRIVILEGES IN SCHEMA myschema GRANT INSERT ON TABLES TO webuser;

ALTER DEFAULT PRIVILEGES IN SCHEMA myschema REVOKE SELECT ON TABLES FROM PUBLIC;
ALTER DEFAULT PRIVILEGES IN SCHEMA myschema REVOKE INSERT ON TABLES FROM webuser;
ALTER DEFAULT PRIVILEGES FOR ROLE admin REVOKE EXECUTE ON FUNCTIONS FROM PUBLIC;
ALTER DEFAULT PRIVILEGES IN SCHEMA public REVOKE EXECUTE ON FUNCTIONS FROM PUBLIC;

reason: ABORT remains for historical reasons but is functionally identical to the standard SQL command ROLLBACK.

The functionality of ALTER GROUP has been generalized under the concept of roles, and similar operations can now be performed using GRANT/REVOKE or ALTER ROLE, which offer more flexibility and additional features.

replaced_by: ALTER TABLE (only for operations applying to indexes)
reason: Simplification and unification of commands by treating ALTER INDEX as an alias for certain ALTER TABLE commands. This also standardizes operations across index-related commands.

examples.code: ALTER INDEX distributors RENAME TO suppliers;
ALTER INDEX distributors SET TABLESPACE fasttablespace;

ALTER INDEX distributors SET (fillfactor = 75);
REINDEX INDEX distributors;

CREATE INDEX coord_idx ON measured (x, y, (z + t));
ALTER INDEX coord_idx ALTER COLUMN 3 SET STATISTICS 1000;

reason: The `ALTER SUBSCRIPTION ... REFRESH PUBLICATION` and `ALTER SUBSCRIPTION ... SET PUBLICATION` commands now include `two_phase` and `failover` properties for enhanced subscription management.

Modification of sub-commands for better handling of table rewrites, metadata updates, and constraints across parent-child relationships. This includes improved handling of default values, index updates, identity columns, and constraints validations.

examples.code: ALTER TABLE distributors ADD COLUMN address varchar(30);

ALTER TABLE measurements
  ADD COLUMN mtime timestamp with time zone DEFAULT now();
ALTER TABLE distributors DROP COLUMN address RESTRICT;

ALTER TABLE foo
    ALTER COLUMN foo_timestamp SET DATA TYPE timestamp with time zone
    USING
        timestamp with time zone 'epoch' + foo_timestamp * interval '1 second';

ALTER TABLE foo
    ALTER COLUMN foo_timestamp DROP DEFAULT,
    ALTER COLUMN foo_timestamp TYPE timestamp with time zone
    USING
        timestamp with time zone 'epoch' + foo_timestamp * interval '1 second',
    ALTER COLUMN foo_timestamp SET DEFAULT now();
ALTER TABLE distributors RENAME COLUMN address TO city;
ALTER TABLE distributors RENAME TO suppliers;
ALTER TABLE distributors RENAME CONSTRAINT zipchk TO zip_check;
ALTER TABLE distributors ALTER COLUMN street SET NOT NULL;
ALTER TABLE distributors ALTER COLUMN street DROP NOT NULL;
ALTER TABLE distributors ADD CONSTRAINT zipchk CHECK (char_length(zipcode) = 5);
ALTER TABLE distributors ADD CONSTRAINT zipchk CHECK (char_length(zipcode) = 5) NO INHERIT;
ALTER TABLE distributors DROP CONSTRAINT zipchk;
ALTER TABLE ONLY distributors DROP CONSTRAINT zipchk;
ALTER TABLE distributors ADD CONSTRAINT distfk FOREIGN KEY (address) REFERENCES addresses (address);

ALTER TABLE distributors ADD CONSTRAINT distfk FOREIGN KEY (address) REFERENCES addresses (address) NOT VALID;
ALTER TABLE distributors VALIDATE CONSTRAINT distfk;
ALTER TABLE distributors ADD CONSTRAINT dist_id_zipcode_key UNIQUE (dist_id, zipcode);
ALTER TABLE distributors ADD PRIMARY KEY (dist_id);
ALTER TABLE distributors SET TABLESPACE fasttablespace;
ALTER TABLE myschema.distributors SET SCHEMA yourschema;

ALTER TABLE measurement
    ATTACH PARTITION measurement_y2016m07 FOR VALUES FROM ('2016-07-01') TO ('2016-08-01');

ALTER TABLE cities
    ATTACH PARTITION cities_ab FOR VALUES IN ('a', 'b');

ALTER TABLE orders
    ATTACH PARTITION orders_p4 FOR VALUES WITH (MODULUS 4, REMAINDER 3);

ALTER TABLE cities
    ATTACH PARTITION cities_partdef DEFAULT;

ALTER TABLE measurement
    DETACH PARTITION measurement_y2015m12;

reason: Consolidation of functionality for user and role management, as users and roles are conceptually aligned under the 'ROLE' abstraction in PostgreSQL.

examples.code:
ALTER USERrole_specification[ WITH ]option[ ... ]whereoptioncan be:SUPERUSER | NOSUPERUSER
    | CREATEDB | NOCREATEDB
    | CREATEROLE | NOCREATEROLE
    | INHERIT | NOINHERIT
    | LOGIN | NOLOGIN
    | REPLICATION | NOREPLICATION
    | BYPASSRLS | NOBYPASSRLS
    | CONNECTION LIMITconnlimit| [ ENCRYPTED ] PASSWORD 'password' | PASSWORD NULL
    | VALID UNTIL 'timestamp'

ALTER USERnameRENAME TOnew_nameALTER USER {role_specification| ALL } [ IN DATABASEdatabase_name] SETconfiguration_parameter{ TO | = } {value| DEFAULT }
ALTER USER {role_specification| ALL } [ IN DATABASEdatabase_name] SETconfiguration_parameterFROM CURRENT
ALTER USER {role_specification| ALL } [ IN DATABASEdatabase_name] RESETconfiguration_parameterALTER USER {role_specification| ALL } [ IN DATABASEdatabase_name] RESET ALLwhererole_specificationcan be:role_name| CURRENT_ROLE
  | CURRENT_USER
  | SESSION_USER

reason: BEGIN was modified to align more closely with SQL standards as its functionality overlaps with START TRANSACTION. Both commands now offer equivalent functionality, reflecting PostgreSQL's effort to maintain compliance and improve consistency with the SQL-standard.

The syntax for the CLUSTER command was updated in PostgreSQL 18 to provide additional options and flexibility, replacing the simpler syntax used before PostgreSQL 17. This change ensures better compatibility for future developments and additional functionality.
Improved compatibility and performance for advanced querying, such as copying rows from partitioned tables, inheritance child tables, or views.

examples.code: COPY (SELECT * FROM country WHERE country_name LIKE 'A%') TO '/usr1/proj/bray/sql/a_list_countries.copy';

reason: The firing order of CHECK constraints on domain types was previously unspecified. Starting from version 9.5, CHECK constraints are tested in alphabetical order by name for predictable behavior.
The keyword PROCEDURE was historically used but is now deprecated in favor of FUNCTION, because the referenced function must be classified as a function in PostgreSQL, not as a procedure.
The CREATE GROUP statement is now considered redundant and has been aliased to CREATE ROLE for better compatibility and ease of use.
The form of CREATE LANGUAGE without a handler function was deemed obsolete and replaced for backward compatibility and consistency with the handling of procedural languages packaged as extensions.
The use of the keyword PROCEDURE has been deprecated due to its inconsistency with the requirement that it refers to a function (not a procedure). The keyword FUNCTION is recommended instead.

replaced_by: CREATE FUNCTION (in certain cases, based on specific use cases)
reason: The PostgreSQL implementation extends the CREATE PROCEDURE API for compatibility with the SQL standard but includes functionality overlapping with CREATE FUNCTION, which may require users to make distinctions between the two for specific procedural needs.

Prior to PostgreSQL 10, an empty string used for the PASSWORD parameter would result in ambiguous behavior that depended on the authentication method and version. Starting from PostgreSQL 10, an empty string explicitly sets the password to null, standardizing behavior.

examples.code: ExamplesCreate a role that can log in, but don't give it a password:CREATE ROLE jonathan LOGIN;Create a role with a password:CREATE USER davide WITH PASSWORD 'jw8s0F4';(CREATE USERis the same asCREATE ROLEexcept that it impliesLOGIN.)Create a role with a password that is valid until the end of 2004. After one second has ticked in 2005, the password is no longer valid.CREATE ROLE miriam WITH LOGIN PASSWORD 'jw8s0F4' VALID UNTIL '2005-01-01';Create a role that can create databases and manage roles:CREATE ROLE admin WITH CREATEDB CREATEROLE;

ExamplesCreate a role that can log in, but don't give it a password:CREATE ROLE jonathan LOGIN;Create a role with a password:CREATE USER davide WITH PASSWORD 'jw8s0F4';(CREATE USERis the same asCREATE ROLEexcept that it impliesLOGIN.)Create a role with a password that is valid until the end of 2004. After one second has ticked in 2005, the password is no longer valid.CREATE ROLE miriam WITH LOGIN PASSWORD 'jw8s0F4' VALID UNTIL '2005-01-01';Create a role that can create databases and manage roles:CREATE ROLE admin WITH CREATEDB CREATEROLE;

ExamplesCreate a role that can log in, but don't give it a password:CREATE ROLE jonathan LOGIN;Create a role with a password:CREATE USER davide WITH PASSWORD 'jw8s0F4';(CREATE USERis the same asCREATE ROLEexcept that it impliesLOGIN.)Create a role with a password that is valid until the end of 2004. After one second has ticked in 2005, the password is no longer valid.CREATE ROLE miriam WITH LOGIN PASSWORD 'jw8s0F4' VALID UNTIL '2005-01-01';Create a role that can create databases and manage roles:CREATE ROLE admin WITH CREATEDB CREATEROLE;

ExamplesCreate a role that can log in, but don't give it a password:CREATE ROLE jonathan LOGIN;Create a role with a password:CREATE USER davide WITH PASSWORD 'jw8s0F4';(CREATE USERis the same asCREATE ROLEexcept that it impliesLOGIN.)Create a role with a password that is valid until the end of 2004. After one second has ticked in 2005, the password is no longer valid.CREATE ROLE miriam WITH LOGIN PASSWORD 'jw8s0F4' VALID UNTIL '2005-01-01';Create a role that can create databases and manage roles:CREATE ROLE admin WITH CREATEDB CREATEROLE;

replaced_by: CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW (preferred for redefining views)
reason: CREATE RULE can be confusing due to its behavior as a command transformation system, especially when handling updates on views. CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW is recommended for simplicity and better performance.

The GLOBAL and LOCAL keywords before TEMPORARY or TEMP are now deprecated as they currently have no effect. Future versions of PostgreSQL might adopt a standard-compliant interpretation of their meaning.

examples.code:
CREATE TABLE films (
    code        char(5),
    title       varchar(40),
    did         integer,
    date_prod   date,
    kind        varchar(10),
    len         interval hour to minute,
    CONSTRAINT production UNIQUE(date_prod)
);

CREATE TABLE films (
    code        char(5),
    title       varchar(40),
    did         integer,
    date_prod   date,
    kind        varchar(10),
    len         interval hour to minute,
    CONSTRAINT code_title PRIMARY KEY(code,title)
);

CREATE TABLE cities_partdef
    PARTITION OF cities DEFAULT;

reason: Certain parameters within the CREATE TABLE AS command, such as `WITH OIDS` and `[ GLOBAL | LOCAL ]`, were deprecated or removed for compatibility reasons and adherence to modern standards.

examples.code:
CREATE TABLE films_recent AS
  SELECT * FROM films WHERE date_prod >= '2002-01-01';

CREATE TABLE films2 AS
  TABLE films;

reason: CREATE USER is now an alias for CREATE ROLE. This change ensures consistency in defining database roles, with LOGIN assumed by default for CREATE USER and NOLOGIN assumed for CREATE ROLE.
Adherence to SQL standards with certain PostgreSQL-specific extensions; changes in order of trigger execution and limitations in transition tables for column-specific updates.

examples.code:
CREATE TRIGGER check_update
    BEFORE UPDATE ON accounts
    FOR EACH ROW
    EXECUTE FUNCTION check_account_update();

CREATE OR REPLACE TRIGGER check_update
    BEFORE UPDATE OF balance ON accounts
    FOR EACH ROW
    EXECUTE FUNCTION check_account_update();

CREATE TRIGGER check_update
    BEFORE UPDATE ON accounts
    FOR EACH ROW
    WHEN (OLD.balance IS DISTINCT FROM NEW.balance)
    EXECUTE FUNCTION check_account_update();

CREATE TRIGGER log_update
    AFTER UPDATE ON accounts
    FOR EACH ROW
    WHEN (OLD.* IS DISTINCT FROM NEW.*)
    EXECUTE FUNCTION log_account_update();

CREATE TRIGGER view_insert
    INSTEAD OF INSERT ON my_view
    FOR EACH ROW
    EXECUTE FUNCTION view_insert_row();

CREATE TRIGGER transfer_insert
    AFTER INSERT ON transfer
    REFERENCING NEW TABLE AS inserted
    FOR EACH STATEMENT
    EXECUTE FUNCTION check_transfer_balances_to_zero();

CREATE TRIGGER paired_items_update
    AFTER UPDATE ON paired_items
    REFERENCING NEW TABLE AS newtab OLD TABLE AS oldtab
    FOR EACH ROW
    EXECUTE FUNCTION check_matching_pairs();

replaced_by: Enhanced CREATE TYPE command with shell-type creation syntax
reason: Simplification of the API for creating new base types and to avoid accidental catalog clutter due to implicit shell type creation from input function definitions.
DROP GROUP is now an alias for DROP ROLE due to simplification and alignment with the design philosophy that groups are roles.
Most procedural languages were converted into extensions starting with PostgreSQL 9.1. As a result, they should now be removed using DROP EXTENSION instead of DROP LANGUAGE.
DROP OWNED is often used for preparing the removal of roles, but REASSIGN OWNED provides an alternative that deals with ownership reassignment without affecting privileges.
Standardization to align with SQL standard and enhance compatibility with other database systems.
Simplification and unification of commands for handling database roles, as the concept of roles subsumes users.

The syntax for EXPLAIN was updated in PostgreSQL 9.0 to support named options in any order, replacing the previous fixed-order syntax for options. This change provides more flexibility and extensibility for future features.

examples.code:
EXPLAIN SELECT * FROM foo;

                       QUERY PLAN
---------------------------------------------------------
 Seq Scan on foo  (cost=0.00..155.00 rows=10000 width=4)
(1 row)

EXPLAIN (FORMAT JSON) SELECT * FROM foo;
           QUERY PLAN
--------------------------------
 [                             +
   {                           +
     "Plan": {                 +
       "Node Type": "Seq Scan",+
       "Relation Name": "foo", +
       "Alias": "foo",         +
       "Startup Cost": 0.00,   +
       "Total Cost": 155.00,   +
       "Plan Rows": 10000,     +
       "Plan Width": 4         +
     }                         +
   }                           +
 ]
(1 row)

EXPLAIN SELECT * FROM foo WHERE i = 4;

                         QUERY PLAN
--------------------------------------------------------------
 Index Scan using fi on foo  (cost=0.00..5.98 rows=1 width=4)
   Index Cond: (i = 4)
(2 rows)

EXPLAIN (FORMAT YAML) SELECT * FROM foo WHERE i='4';
          QUERY PLAN
-------------------------------
 - Plan:                      +
     Node Type: "Index Scan"  +
     Scan Direction: "Forward"+
     Index Name: "fi"         +
     Relation Name: "foo"     +
     Alias: "foo"             +
     Startup Cost: 0.00       +
     Total Cost: 5.98         +
     Plan Rows: 1             +
     Plan Width: 4            +
     Index Cond: "(i = 4)"
(1 row)

EXPLAIN (COSTS FALSE) SELECT * FROM foo WHERE i = 4;

        QUERY PLAN
----------------------------
 Index Scan using fi on foo
   Index Cond: (i = 4)
(2 rows)

EXPLAIN SELECT sum(i) FROM foo WHERE i < 10;

                             QUERY PLAN
-------------------------------------------------------------------​--
 Aggregate  (cost=23.93..23.93 rows=1 width=4)
   ->  Index Scan using fi on foo  (cost=0.00..23.92 rows=6 width=4)
         Index Cond: (i < 10)
(3 rows)

PREPARE query(int, int) AS SELECT sum(bar) FROM test
    WHERE id > $1 AND id < $2
    GROUP BY foo;

EXPLAIN ANALYZE EXECUTE query(100, 200);

                                                       QUERY PLAN
-------------------------------------------------------------------​------------------------------------------------------
 HashAggregate  (cost=10.77..10.87 rows=10 width=12) (actual time=0.043..0.044 rows=10.00 loops=1)
   Group Key: foo
   Batches: 1  Memory Usage: 24kB
   Buffers: shared hit=4
   ->  Index Scan using test_pkey on test  (cost=0.29..10.27 rows=99 width=8) (actual time=0.009..0.025 rows=99.00 loops=1)
         Index Cond: ((id > 100) AND (id < 200))
         Index Searches: 1
         Buffers: shared hit=4
 Planning Time: 0.244 ms
 Execution Time: 0.073 ms
(10 rows)

EXPLAIN (GENERIC_PLAN)
  SELECT sum(bar) FROM test
    WHERE id > $1 AND id < $2
    GROUP BY foo;

                                  QUERY PLAN
-------------------------------------------------------------------​------------
 HashAggregate  (cost=26.79..26.89 rows=10 width=12)
   Group Key: foo
   ->  Index Scan using test_pkey on test  (cost=0.29..24.29 rows=500 width=8)
         Index Cond: ((id > $1) AND (id < $2))
(4 rows)

EXPLAIN (GENERIC_PLAN)
  SELECT sum(bar) FROM test
    WHERE id > $1::integer AND id < $2::integer
    GROUP BY foo;

reason: The SQL standard introduced the MERGE statement, which allows combining INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE logic in a single statement.

examples.code:
INSERT INTO films VALUES
    ('UA502', 'Bananas', 105, '1971-07-13', 'Comedy', '82 minutes');

INSERT INTO films (code, title, did, date_prod, kind)
    VALUES ('T_601', 'Yojimbo', 106, '1961-06-16', 'Drama');
INSERT INTO films DEFAULT VALUES;
INSERT INTO films SELECT * FROM tmp_films WHERE date_prod < '2004-05-07';

INSERT INTO distributors (did, dname) VALUES (DEFAULT, 'XYZ Widgets')
   RETURNING did;

INSERT INTO distributors (did, dname)
    VALUES (5, 'Gizmo Transglobal'), (6, 'Associated Computing, Inc')
    ON CONFLICT (did) DO UPDATE SET dname = EXCLUDED.dname
    RETURNING old.did AS old_did, old.dname AS old_dname,
              new.did AS new_did, new.dname AS new_dname;

INSERT INTO distributors (did, dname) VALUES (7, 'Redline GmbH')
    ON CONFLICT (did) DO NOTHING;

reason: To provide an alternative syntax with consistent behavior and clearer semantics for resetting runtime parameters.

examples.code: RESET timezone;

reason: In PostgreSQL 16, dependent privileges were not tracked for grants of role membership, and thus the CASCADE option had no effect for role membership. This behavior was changed to ensure consistent privilege tracking.

examples.code: REVOKE INSERT ON films FROM PUBLIC;
REVOKE ALL PRIVILEGES ON kinds FROM manuel;
REVOKE admins FROM joe;

reason: SELECT INTO is less flexible compared to CREATE TABLE AS, which allows specifying properties like access method and tablespace.

In PostgreSQL versions 8.0 through 8.2, the effects of `SET LOCAL` were canceled by releasing an earlier savepoint or exiting a PL/pgSQL exception block, which was considered unintuitive. This behavior has been changed to improve usability.

examples.code: SET search_path TO my_schema, public;
SET datestyle TO postgres, dmy;

reason: For simplicity, compatibility with SQL standard, and historical usage, PostgreSQL allows both START TRANSACTION and BEGIN for initiating transaction blocks.
The command syntax changed to allow the options to be specified in any order, rather than requiring a specific order.

examples.code: VACUUM (VERBOSE, ANALYZE) onek;
